titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Dick family collection 1985.001
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham (2011); Updated by John Zarrillo (2014)
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-07-25 15:24:40 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

physdesc.extent: in two folders, one oversize folder, and two tintypes.

did.abstract: The Dick family collection includes correspondence, wills, deeds, mortgages, military records, clippings, illustrations and two tintypes. The collection relates primarily to Archibald L. Dick, an engraver, and James L. Dick, his son and an artist who was one of the founding members of the Brooklyn Academy of Design.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged by type and size. Several oversize indentures are stored in an oversize box and the collection's two tintypes are housed separately from the documents and engravings.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Archibald L. Dick (c. 1793-1856), a Brooklyn engraver, was once a resident of 66 Fulton Street. His last residence was 157 Gold Street, where James L. Dick (c. 1833-1868), an artist in Brooklyn and Archibald Dick's son, also resided. James Dick was one of the founding members of the Brooklyn Academy of Design in 1866.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Dick family papers, 1985.001, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2024.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Dick family collection dates to 1848-1860 and includes correspondence, wills, deeds, mortgages, military records, clippings, engravings and tintypes.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain.
